channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Syrian Rebels Pull Out of Homs After Long Battle
item.description: Hundreds of people were evacuated from the last rebel-held pocket of the central Syrian city devastated by years of fighting and blockades.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Syrian rebels on a bus as hundreds of people were evacuated on Wednesday from the last rebel-held pocket of Homs.

item.title: Opposition in Venezuela Now Has to Fix the Ills That Led to Its Victory
item.description: Discontent over a failing economy led the opposition to an overwhelming majority in elections on Sunday, but victory sets up a power struggle between the Assembly and President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Jesús Torrealba, center, secretary of the Venezuelan coalition of opposition parties, at a news conference in Caracas on Tuesday.

item.title: British Petition to Keep Donald Trump Out of Country
item.description: Angered by the candidate’s comments about Muslims, more than 100,000 people have signed the petition to bar him from Britain on hate-speech grounds.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A screen grab of a petition calling for Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, to be barred from entering Britain.

item.title: As Beijing Shuts Down Over Smog Alert, Worse-Off Neighbors Carry On
item.description: The patchwork emergency response in northern China pointed to a major shortcoming of efforts by officials to battle air pollution and protect residents.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: People filming a flag-raising ceremony during heavy smog at Tiananmen Square in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Afghan Forces Clear Most Taliban From Kandahar Airfield
item.description: Officials said 14 attackers were killed but two were at large and the fate of hostages remained unclear as a siege entered its second day.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Afghan security forces inspected the damage after clashes with Taliban militants at a police station in Kandahar, Afghanistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Attack Helicopters May Fight ISIS in Iraq City
item.description: The United States is prepared to deploy the aircraft and advisers to help Iraqi forces in their long-running battle to retake the city of Ramadi.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: An Iraqi security forces member took up a position on Monday a few miles east of Ramadi, where government forces have been closing on Islamic State militants.

item.title: Joe Biden, His Son and the Case Against a Ukrainian Oligarch
item.description: As the vice president aims to curb corruption in Ukraine, Hunter Biden sits on the board of a Ukrainian company accused of having “illicit assets.”
item.dc:creator: JAMES RISEN
item.media:description: Hunter Biden at a campaign event in 2008. He sits on the board of one of Ukraine’s largest natural gas companies.

item.title: German Woman Denies Role in Murders in Neo-Nazi Case
item.description: Beate Zschäpe, in a statement to a Munich court, rejected charges she had been part of an underground cell that killed nine migrants and a policewoman from 2000 to 2007.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Beate Zschäpe, center, with her lawyers at a courtroom in Munich on Wednesday.

item.title: Turning Points: What Defines a Modern Warrior?
item.description: Instead of trying to lift up societies, we’ve narrowed our sights to the hunting and killing of enemies.
item.dc:creator: PHIL KLAY
item.media:description: The photojournalist Ashley Gilbertson has captured the bedrooms of participants in the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan as part of a project to remember who they were. Some parents have kept their children’s personal effects exactly the same as when they left. Army Pfc. Karina S. Lau, 20, died in Fallujah, Iraq, when her helicopter was shot down by insurgents on Nov. 2, 2003. She was from Livingston, California. Her bedroom was photographed in December 2009.

item.title: At Least 9,115 Killed in Ukraine Conflict, U.N. Says
item.description: The pace of the killing has slowed sharply since a cease-fire in August, the monitors said, with only 47 civilians killed and 131 injured in the three months ending in mid-November.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: The burial of pro-Russian fighters in Donetsk, Ukraine, in 2014. In addition to those killed since the outbreak of hostilities, another 20,797 have been injured.

item.title: U.S. Proposes Raising Spending on Climate-Change Adaptation
item.description: The announcement by Secretary of State John Kerry comes just days before 195 countries and the European Union hope to forge a new pact on emissions
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a speech during the United Nations conference on climate change at Le Bourget, just outside Paris, on Wednesday.

item.title: Afghanistan Hopes W.T.O. Membership Can Its Reboot Battered Economy
item.description: Optimists view the trade body’s seal of approval as a potential lift for the war-ravaged country whose chief export is opium and main “import” is international aid.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Afghan farmers harvesting opium sap in a poppy field near Jalalabad. Afghanistan “remains a poor, fragile state far from self-reliance,” an International Monetary Fund report said.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Angela Merkel’s War for Europe
item.description: Why is Germany intervening in Syria? To save the European Union.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: Thai Police Investigate U.S. Ambassador on Suspicion of Insulting King
item.description: The police said that the ambassador, Glyn T. Davies, had diplomatic immunity, but that they were obliged by law to investigate the complaint.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese-Language Readers Speak Out on the Emissions Challenge
item.description: Asked to comment on pollution and climate change, readers criticized the failure to curb smog but also said that China was being unfairly targeted.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Heavy smog blanketing West Lake in Hangzhou, in the eastern Chinese province of Zhejiang, on Tuesday. Because of industrial coal burning, Chinese cities regularly have among the world’s worst air quality.

item.title: Afghan President Receives Unexpected Welcome in Pakistan
item.description: The size of the greeting party for Ashraf Ghani’s visit was unusual for the leader of a country that has been in a war of words, if not more, for years.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, right, greeted President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan, left, in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: France Identifies 3rd Attacker at Bataclan Concert Hall
item.description: The assailant is said to have been a 23-year-old from the northeastern city of Strasbourg who left for Syria with a group of would-be jihadists in late 2013.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Marshall Journal: They Helped Erase Ebola in Liberia. Now Liberia Is Erasing Them.
item.description: Thirty young men spent months burning the bodies of the infected. A year later, many relatives and fellow countrymen still can’t forgive them.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: The now-abandoned crematory in Marshall, Liberia, last month. Some of the 30 young men who worked there are still haunted by the work they did, and are being ostracized for it.

item.title: Smog So Thick, Beijing Comes to a Standstill
item.description: The poisonous air quality prompted the government to declare a “red alert,” closing schools, forcing motorists to stay off the road and shutting factories.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A building with a screen on it in Beijing on Tuesday was obscured by smog that led to the city’s top level of air pollution warning.

item.title: Memo From Myanmar: Myanmar Political Shift Revives Debate on Sanctions
item.description: The success of the Nov. 8 election, a crucial step in the transition to democracy, has inspired new discussion on the effectiveness of American sanctions and whether to lift those that remain.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the main port terminals in Yangon is owned by Asia World, a company on the sanctions list. The company, founded by one of the country’s premier heroin kingpins, built not only the port but roads, dams and a major Yangon hotel.
